chapter.title: Intro to Python
chapter.para: Python is an all-purpose programming language. It can be used to create desktop applications, 3d graphics, video games, and even websites. It's a good language to learn because it's simpler than complex languages like C, C++, or Java, but is almost as powerful, and is used in just about every industry that uses computers.
Unlike Scratch, Python doesn't have a GUI. You have to type code into a text editor, save the file, and then run it with the Python interpreter.

textobject.para: The Scratch interface is like Python. The Scratch scripts and you make with Scratch blocks are like Python code.

section.title: Installing Python
section.para: Before learning Python, you may need to install it.

Follow the instructions for Linux, above. Macintosh does not have an inbuilt package manager, so if Python 3 is not found, install it from python.org/downloads/mac-osx.
At the time of this writing, Microsoft Windows doesn't yet ship with Python. Install it from python.org/downloads/windows. Be sure to select Add Python to PATH in the install wizard.

section.title: Starting Python 3
section.para: Since you've never used Python before, your first task is to try a few simple one-line programmes with it. You can talk directly to Python by running it in a terminal.

listitem.para: On Linux or macOS, launch a terminal window and type python3
On Windows, launch Python 3 from the Start menu.
If there is no Python in the Start menu, launch Windows PowerShell and type C:\Windows\py.exe
If that doesn't work, try reinstalling Python. Be sure to select Add Python to PATH in the install wizard. Refer to docs.python.org/3/using/windows.html for detailed instructions.
If that doesn't work, make sure you have Python installed, or just use Linux. It's free and doesn't even require you to install it to use it.

section.title: Telling Python what to do
section.para: Just like Scratch has code blocks, Python has keywords that tell Python what you want it to do.
For instance, type this at your Python prompt and then press Return:
The keyword print tells Python to print out whatever text you give it in parentheses and quotes.
That's not very exciting, though. Unlike Scratch, which has probably 100 code blocks ready to use, Python only has access to some basic keywords, like print, help, and so on.
Use the import keyword to load more keywords.
Turtle is a fun module to use. It's exactly like the Pen code blocks in Scratch.
section.programlisting: >>> turtle.begin_fill() >>> turtle.forward(100) >>> turtle.left(90) >>> turtle.forward(100) >>> turtle.left(90) >>> turtle.forward(100) >>> turtle.left(90) >>> turtle.forward(100) >>> turtle.end_fill()

section.title: Exercise
section.para: See what shapes you can draw with the turtle module.
To clear you turtle drawing area, use the turtle.clear() keyword.
What do you think the keyword turtle.color("blue") does?

section.title: Scripting Python
section.para: Now that you've had a chance to play around with Python 3 in the terminal, it's time to write a Python script.

question.para: What is a script in Scratch?

answer.para: It's a list of instructions that controls your programme.

section.para: A script in Python 3 is a lot like a script in Scratch. The difference is that instead of using code blocks, Python 3 uses keywords.
To write a Python script, you must have a text editor.

listitem.para: If you use Linux, you can use whatever editor is already included (common ones are gedit, kate, and mousepad). Alternately, you can try something more advanced, like Atom or Emacs.
On Mac OS, do not use Text Edit, because it's not Python-aware, and it sometimes fails to save files as text. Instead, use gedit or Atom
On Windows, you can use Notepad, but it's not Python-aware. try a good text editor like Notepad++ or Atom.

section.para: Open an empty text file and type this programme. In Python, the indentation matters, so type this exactly as you see it, using the Tab key to indent when necessary.
section.programlisting:
import turtle as t import time
t.color("blue") t.begin_fill()
n=0
while n < 4: t.forward(100) t.left(90)
t.end_fill() time.sleep(5)
section.para: Save the text file as turtle.py.
To run your script, type python3 $MOHE/turtle.py on Linux or macOS. On Windows, type Python.exe turtle.py

Once you have run your script, it's time to explore an even better module. One popular module used to create video games with Python is called PyGame. It's got a lot more features than turtle, but is also a lot more complex, so be prepared.
